steps.title: Work over a drop cloth or workbench.
steps.content: Work over a drop cloth or workbench. The sanding and sealing process can make a mess, so be sure to work in a spot that’s easy to clean. Working over a sheet or drop cloth makes picking up sawdust and leftover sealer much easier. [1] X Research source If it’s a nice day, working outside is always a good choice.

steps.title: Sand the balsa with 220-grit sandpaper.
steps.content: Sand the balsa with 220-grit sandpaper. Use a smooth, back and forth motion to rough up the surface of the wood. [2] X Expert Source Jeff Huynh Professional Handyman Expert Interview. 30 April 2019. Sand all the parts that you’ll be painting so the primer and paint stick better. Apply only light pressure so you don’t cause any holes or uneven spots on the wood. [3] X Research source If you’ll be painting both sides of the wood, like for a model, be sure to sand both sides. If you do rub a little too hard and leave some low spots on the wood, that’s okay. The wood filler can fix that.

steps.title: Brush on a coat of wood filler to seal the wood surface.
steps.content: Brush on a coat of wood filler to seal the wood surface. Dip a normal paintbrush into a bottle of wood filler. Then brush a thick layer of filler onto the entire balsa surface until you can't see the wood grain underneath. Don’t miss any spots or the paint will be uneven. [4] X Research source Many hobbyists recommend Elmer’s Wood Filler Light for this job, but any other wood filler will also work. Don’t worry if the filler drips or runs a little. You can fix that when you sand the wood. You need to mix some wood fillers with water first to thin them out. Always read and follow the instructions on the wood filler that you use, just in case they’re different.

steps.title: Let the wood filler dry for about 2-8 hours.
steps.content: Let the wood filler dry for about 2-8 hours. Leave the wood out in a spot where it won’t be disturbed. Wait for it to dry completely before moving on. [5] X Research source The wood filler dry time varies, but is usually around 2 hours. Thicker types might take up to 8 hours. Follow the recommended drying time on the product you use.

steps.title: Sand the wood again with 220-grit sandpaper.
steps.content: Sand the wood again with 220-grit sandpaper. [6] X Expert Source Jeff Huynh Professional Handyman Expert Interview. 30 April 2019. Use the same fine-grit sandpaper that you first sanded the wood with. Continue sanding until you can see the wood grain through the wood filler. This gives you a nice smooth surface for the paint to stick to. [7] X Research source Be sure to sand the corners and edges if you’re painting the whole piece of wood. Otherwise the paint might not stick as well in these spots. If there are any spots where the wood filler dripped, you can even these out with the sandpaper. Sanding the filler off will make a lot of dust, so be ready to wipe that up when you're done.

steps.title: Work outside or in a well-ventilated area.
steps.content: Work outside or in a well-ventilated area. Spray paint and primer is best for balsa wood. The only problem is this creates a lot of fumes. Be sure to work outdoors or open all the windows in the area you’re working to protect yourself. You could use brush-on primer and paint too, but apply a very light coat. They could drip and ruin the finish. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Spray a coat of sandable primer onto the wood.
steps.content: Spray a coat of sandable primer onto the wood. Shake the can of primer well and hold it 6–12 in (15–30 cm) from the wood. Spray in a sweeping motion until you cover the entire surface. Keep the can moving so the primer doesn’t pool or drip. [9] X Research source You need to use sandable primer because you’ll be sanding it between coats. [10] X Expert Source Jeff Huynh Professional Handyman Expert Interview. 30 April 2019. Primer is important because the paints won’t stick properly without it, so don’t skip this step.

steps.title: Sand the primer when it’s dry with 400-grit sandpaper.
steps.content: Sand the primer when it’s dry with 400-grit sandpaper. Wait until the primer is completely dry. Then, use this very fine-grit sandpaper and give the wood a light sanding. [11] X Research source The drying time depends, and could range from an hour to a full day. Follow the instructions on the primer you use.

steps.title: Apply 2 more coats of primer.
steps.content: Apply 2 more coats of primer. Spray another coat of primer the same as before, and let it dry. Sand it afterward and spray on a final coat. [12] X Expert Source Jeff Huynh Professional Handyman Expert Interview. 30 April 2019. This gives you a nice, even finish when you paint. [13] X Research source Normally, 1-2 coats of primer is fine, but you need the extra coat because balsa wood is very soft.

steps.title: Tape off sections that will be a different color.
steps.content: Tape off sections that will be a different color. If you’re making a model or using a decorative pattern, then you’ll want nice, even lines for your paint. Use painter’s tape and cover any areas that will be a different color from the first coat. [14] X Research source On model rockets, for example, the nose is usually a different color from the body. Cover the nose with tape, paint the body, then remove the tape and paint the nose separately. Hobbyists recommend plain masking tape or clear Scotch tape along with painter’s tape for the best results. Don’t use a tape that’s sticky, like packing or duct tape. This will leave residue on the wood and ruin the finish.

steps.title: Spray a light coat of enamel or latex paint onto the wood and let it dry.
steps.content: Spray a light coat of enamel or latex paint onto the wood and let it dry. These are the best paint types for balsa. Shake the can well and hold it 12 in (30 cm) away from the wood. Spray in a sweeping, back and forth motion to cover the wood. Only apply a light coat so the paint doesn’t run. [15] X Research source Keep the can 12 in (30 cm) away from wood so the finish is even. It’s okay if the paint looks blotchy or you can still see the wood underneath. This is just a light coat, and it’ll even out with later coats. Just like with primer, you could also use a brush-on paint too. But remember to apply very light coats so the paint doesn’t run.

steps.title: Keep applying paint after the previous coat dries until the finish is even.
steps.content: Keep applying paint after the previous coat dries until the finish is even. Let the first coat dry completely, then spray on another light coat. [16] X Expert Source Jeff Huynh Professional Handyman Expert Interview. 30 April 2019. Let it dry, and continue until you have a nice, even finish that doesn’t show the wood grain underneath it. [17] X Research source The drying time varies depending on the paint you use. Always check and confirm the right drying time. The number of coats you’ll need varies, but expect to apply 3-4 for an even finish.

steps.title: Paint the remaining sections if they were covered with tape.
steps.content: Paint the remaining sections if they were covered with tape. If you taped off any sections of the wood, peel the tape off when the first color is completely dry. Then cover that section with tape and spray the second color on. [18] X Research source If you only used one color, then there’s no need to tape or paint anymore.

steps.title: Let the paint cure entirely for 2-3 days.
steps.content: Let the paint cure entirely for 2-3 days. The paint can take anywhere from 36 to 72 hours to completely cure. Leave the wood alone for that time and let the paint cure, then you can move it where you want it. [19] X Research source Check the instructions on the paint you use for the proper curing time.
